data.title: greeting card
data.meta_description: GREETING CARD meaning: 1. a piece of thick paper folded in half with a picture on the outside and a message inside, that…. Learn more.
data.text:
noun [ C ]

US us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈɡriː.t̬ɪŋ ˌkɑːrd/ uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈɡriː.tɪŋ ˌkɑːd/ (UK greetings card)

a piece of thick paper folded in half with a picture on the outside and a message inside, that you write in and send or give to someone, for example at Christmas or on his or her birthday

JGI/Jamie Grill/Blend Images/GettyImages

(Definition of greeting card from the Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary & Thesaurus © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of greeting card

greeting card

There is no greeting card to capture both this powerful sense of loss, but also profound wellspring of memories.

Greeting card companies also have criticized the plans.

There are a lot of things they can infer about me even from a greeting card.

We always signed a greeting card with everybody's name on it.

For example, an application that lets users send friends an electronic greeting card might need to know their birthday or anniversary.

A line that has even more fatally, gratingly become a greeting card sentiment when detached from its context.

I'm not trying to sound like a greeting card about "the spirit of giving", but this is really about the spirit of avoiding frustration.

Though he lacked a formal education, he was a shrewd businessman, and he built an enduring legacy in the greeting card industry.

The retired sales executive for a greeting card company and part-time tax preparer was terrified he'd had a heart attack or a stroke.

If watching those ads doesn't bring a tear to your eye and send you off to buy a greeting card, you just don't have a heart.

It began with a simple greeting card.

Thick greeting cards can conceal banned substances, but they still are permitted - for now.

She designs her own greeting cards that are stamped or covered with glitter or felt.

Royalties were most often collected from stage productions, television shows, movies or greeting cards.

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.
